title: Filthy Tiddles
body:
We all knew this day would come - Tuesday, April 19th, 2005. It was inevitable. It was right there on the calendar all along.

Sorry I didn't post yesterday, but I've been busier than two muskrats copulating in a wool sock in the desert. No. Wait a minute. That's my analogy for being hot. I guess I don't have one for being busy. Oh well.

Work has officially begun on the theater. My dad and I built the first false wall for the Cinebar (expect a phlog in the near future). OH YEAH, and speaking of the Cinebar:

The winner of the Cinebar auction was none other than Springfield's own Steve Olson! Steve is a frequent blog reader (you probably know him as Ole), and has helped keep my and Nicole's finances in check by tossing a few odd jobs our way on occasion (thanks!). Steve's a marketing consultant here in town, but he won't be naming the Cinebar after his consulting firm. Instead, he's going to name the Cinebar after one of his websites, SGFsoccer.com. Steve's a huge soccer fan - he played the sport for 20+ years and currently coaches the Pershing soccer team - so he decided to create a website that would centralize information, promote local teams from the high school up through college levels, and showcase his soccer videography skills. So, a big CONGRATULATIONS to Mr. Olson and the SGFsoccer.com Cinebar!

On that same note, we've decided to continue the tradition of auctioning off the Cinebars naming rights on an annual basis. Every year, on or around our anniversary mark, we'll auction off the naming rights for the preceding year, but instead of pocketing the money ourselves, the proceeds will fund an annual grant for a local independent film-maker. Woo hoo!

Let's see, what else...

We should be getting the new bids on electrical and HVAC sometime this week. I'm hoping the new quotes will shave at least $15K off our initial estimates, but I'm not holding my breath.

However, if the bids come back and they're STILL too high, we have alternate avenues of funding the theater. Llama black market.

Ha ha, just kidding.

Or am I?

Llama.

I just realized something - I never fully explained why our initial bids were so ridiculously high. Here's a quick breakdown:

Electrical - I supplied the engineers with bad data, which led them to believe we needed to upgrade to 600 amps. After discovering my mistake, the plans are being scaled down to a 400 amp upgrade... a HUGE difference. I'm hoping this will save us somewhere in the neighborhood of between $10K to $15K, but I have nothing to base that on other than a really funny Bazooka Joe comic.

HVAC - Or initial bid specified that the heat exchanger - a somehwat simple piece of machinery that sucked in outside air, conditioned it, and spit it into the auditorium - would cost us over $10,000. But, after speaking with the engineer, we were told the heat exchanger sells for roughly $2,100...

*mouth drops open*

So why did the subcontractor bid the heat exchanger to us at 5x the initial cost? Who knows. Seriously. Who among you knows? I want answers!!! Chris (GC) is currently investigating. After the dust settles, I'm hoping to save anywhere between $5K to $8K, but again... I have nothing to base that on.

I have more to mention, but I'm running out of time to type it out in length, so here's a CNN Headline News overview of what's left:

- On April 24th, a movie called Homemade HillBilly Jam is premiering at Canada's Hot Docs Documentary Festival in Toronto. The documentary is all about Springfield's most popular band, Big Smith. My goal is to get in touch with Mark Bilyeu and coordinate something - ANYTHING - with him and the band. Any suggestions?

- Why the title "Filthy Tiddles?" Why not?

- I think KY3 is running a little tiddle about the Moxie tonight. I'm meeting with them at 10:00.

- When I was 13 years old, I perfected a fighting move known as "The Raptor." It consisted of running and jumping towards your opponent while frantically kicking your feet and punching your fists. The only way to effectively counter this move is to quickly move out of the way. Still, 12 years later, I can't think of a way to counter that defense.
author: Dan

comments.author: whitty
comments.body:
Um, Jodi Bilyeu was my poetry professor, sometimes I see him and I am like, "Hey." and he is like, "Hey."... and I went to school with his cousin... and my grandparents live two hollers over from his uncle.... yeah, I got nothing.

I blame the rogue 'i' on the creepy little Jodie girl in Amityville Horror.
